thread.title: Tasmania urges Commonwealth to follow moves to ban super trawlers

author: Sallese Gibson
title: Tasmania urges Commonwealth to follow moves to ban super trawlers

organizations.name: game fish tasmania sports fishing club

text:
Map: TAS 
The State Government has moved to ban super trawlers from Tasmanian waters and urged the Federal Government to follow suit. 
Tasmanian regulations have prevented trawlers over 38 metres in length from fishing in state waters since 2001, but the State Government wants to strengthen the ban through legislation. 
The vessels have long caused controversy in Tasmania , with multiple attempts by local fishing company SeaFish Tasmania to have super trawlers based in the state to operate in Commonwealth waters. 
In Ulverstone yesterday, Primary Industries Minister Jeremy Rockliff announced the Government would introduce a bill in March banning trawling in Tasmanian waters. 
"Super trawling and trawling is banned by regulation," he said. 
"We're strengthening that ban through its own legislation, so in order for that to be reversed, to allow trawling in our states, [it] would have to be through an act of Parliament. 
"This is a very big barrier to ever bringing back trawling and super trawling into Tasmanian waters." 
The move, which was a 2014 election commitment, is designed to protect the $100 million-a-year recreational fishing industry. 
"Significant money and funds flow through our economy when it comes to the value of recreational fishing," Mr Rockliff said. Photo: Mr Rockliff, centre, says the new bill will protect recreational fishing. (ABC News: Sallese Gibson) 
"[Legislation] protects the interests of recreational fishing and indeed the significant contribution [it makes] to our local economy." 
Tasmanian Association for Recreational Fishing (TARFish) chief executive Mark Nikolai welcomed the move, saying fishers wanted long-term protection for the industry. 
"Putting it in legislation, as opposed to just having it sitting there in the management rules for the particular fishery, strengthens that protection," he said. 
"Now, it's got to go to Parliament and both sides of Parliament have to agree to make those changes, so the ability of a minister or for anybody to put those changes into place is significantly more difficult into the future." 'Commonwealth ban needed' 
But Nobby Clark from Game Fish Tasmania Sports Fishing Club said the move was a "stunt", as state waters only extended around five kilometres offshore. 
"From five kilometres out to 200 miles is Commonwealth waters," he said. 
"The majority of recreational offshore fishing takes place outside state waters ... and that's where we've been seeking protection." 
Mr Clark said any meaningful change required a total ban on trawling in Commonwealth waters. 
"It's the protection of the adjacent Commonwealth fishery that we've been seeking, so unfortunately it just seems a little bit hollow, to be honest," he said. 
Currently, super trawlers longer than 130 metres are banned from fishing in Australian waters by regulation. 
Mr Rockliff said the State Government had written to Federal Agriculture Minister Barnaby Joyce, pushing for the federal ban to be strengthened by legislation. 
"We haven't heard back yet from the Federal Government but we anticipate a response in the near future," he said. 
Mr Nikolai said TARFish was also lobbying for change at a Commonwealth level. 
"We've been having those same discussions at a Commonwealth level since 2012," he said. 
"It's extremely important that the Commonwealth Government listen to the recreational fishing sector â€” not just in Tasmania but across Australia." 
The Federal Government said it banned super trawlers over 130 metres in length in 2015 by regulation.
